facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 484 to 489 of 1958 by special leave from the judgement and order dated August 6, 1954, of the U.P. Board of Revenue, Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 484 to 489 of 1958. Appeals by special leave from the judgement and order dated August 6, 1954, of the U.P. Board of Revenue, Allahabad, in petitions Nos. 203 to 208 of 1947-48.

facts.text: Appellants presented applications against each set of the respondents under s.175, U.P. Tenancy Act, 1939 for ejectment stating they were sir-holders of the land occupied by respondents as non-occupancy tenants and the five-year period under s.20 had expired.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants presented applications against each set of the respondents in these six appeals under s.175, U.P. Tenancy Act, 1939 U.P. XVII of 1939, hereinafter called the Act, for ejectment stating that they were the sir-bolders of the land occupied by the respondents as number-occupancy tenants and that the period of five years during which the respondents were entitled to retain possession under s.20 of the Act had expired.

facts.text: Respondents contested notice of ejectment alleging land was not sir, appellants not sir-holders, paid local rate exceeding Rs.25/- in United Provinces, held more than 50 acres of sir land, claimed hereditary tenants under ss.14,15,16.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companytested the numberice of ejectment alleging that the land in suit was number air, that the appellants were number sir-holders, that appellants paid local rate exceeding Rs. 25/-in the United Provinces, Agra and Oudh, and held more than 50 acres of sir land. They claimed to be hereditary tenants of the land in dispute, in accordance with ss. 14, 15 and 16 of the Act.

facts.text: Papers forwarded by Tehsildar to Assistant Collector in charge of sub-division per s.179; applications deemed plaints, proceedings continued as suits per sub-s.2 s.179.

anchor.surface_text: The paper were thereafter forwarded by the Tehsilder to the Assistant Collector in charge of the sub-division, in accordance with the provisions of s. 179 of the Act The applications which were presented for the ejectment of the respondents were deemed to be plaints and the proceedings companytinued as suits, in view of sub-s.  2  of a. 179 of the Act.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer decreed suits on February 28, 1946: land sir, appellants sir-holders, each did not pay local rate >Rs.25/- in 1938 or 1940, did not hold >50 acres sir or sir+khudkasht not sublet in 1317F.

anchor.surface_text: The sub-Divisional Officer did number accept the companytention of the respondents and decreed the suits on February 28, 1946, holding that the land in suit was air, that the appellants were air-holders, that each of them did number pay a local rate exceeding Rs. 25/- either in 1938 or in 1940, that he did number hold more than fifty acres of air land or more than fifty acres of air and khudkasht land which had number been sublet in 1317 F., companyresponding to the period from July 1, 1939 to June 30,1940.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to Additional Commissioner, Benaras, repeating contentions; also contended non-compliance with s.19 as amended by U.P. Tenancy Amendment Act, 1947 (U.P. X of 1947) effective June 14, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents appealed against the decree to the Additional Commissioner, Benaras, and repeated their companytentions which had number found favour in the Trial Court. They also companytended that the appellants had number companyplied with the requirements of s, 19 of the Act as amended by the P. Tenancy  Amendment  Act, 1947  U.P. X of 1947  which came in to force on June 14. 1947 after the appeals had been instituted.

facts.text: Additional Commissioner confirmed SDO findings, held substantial compliance with amended s.19, dismissed appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Commissioner companyfirmed the findings of the Sub-Divisional Officer and further hold that there had been substantial companypliance with the spiritof the law as laid down in the amended a. 19 of the Act. He accordingly dismissed the appeals.

facts.text: Board of Revenue disagreed on compliance with amended s.19 and rules, set aside decree, remanded for fresh disposal including decision on adivasi rights under U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 (U.P.1 of 1951).

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Revenue did number agree with the additional Commissioner about there having been sufficient companypliance with the provisions of amended a. 19 of the Act and of the rules framed thereunder. It therefore set aside the decree against the respondents and remanded the cases for fresh disposal in accordance with law and further directed the Trial Court to decide the further companytention raised by the respondents before the Board to the effect that they had acquired adivasi rights in the land in suit after the companying into force of the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  U. P. 1 of 1951 .

facts.text: U.P. Tenancy Act, 1939 came into force on January 1, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The land in suit was sir on January 1, 1940, when the Act came into force.

facts.text: Appellants proved land was sir on Jan 1, 1940; each sir-holder not assessed >Rs.25/- local rate; not assessed >Rs.25/- on June 30, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from these provisions that the appellants bad to establish the following facts  i  The land in suit was sir on January 1, 1940, when the Act came into force.  ii  Each sir-holder was number assessed in the United Provinces to a local rate of more than Rs. 25/-.  iii  The sir holder or his predecessor in interest was number assessed to a local rate exceeding Rs. 25/- on June 30, 1938.

facts.text: Trial court held land did not cease to be sir; each sir holder had less than 50 acres sir or sir+khudkasht.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants proved these facts and the trial Court held that the land in suit did number cease to be sir. Further, if the finding had been that the first proviso to s. 6 applied, s. 16 would have companye into play and it would have been necessary for the Court to determine whether each of the sir holders possessed more than fifty acres of sir or of sir and khudkasht land which had number been let. On this point too, the finding of the Trial Court, however, is that each sir holder bad less than fifty acres of sir and khudkasht land.

facts.text: U.P. Tenancy Amendment Act, 1947 came into force on June 14, 1947.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on August 31, 1962 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. August 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-

facts.text: Appellants filed documents: khewats 1345-1347 Fasli, khatauni jamabandis 1345,1347 Fasli, statements of shares, areas, local rates, pedigree.

anchor.surface_text: The documents filed by the appellants in the Trial Court companysisted of  1  khewats of the various villages for the years 1345, 1346 and 1347 Fasli, i.e. for the periods between July 1, 1937 to June 30, 1940  2  khatauni jamabandis of the various villages for the years 1345 and 1347 Fasli, companyresponding to July 1, 1937 to June 30, 1938 and July 1, 1939 to June 30, 1940, respectively  3   a  a statement showing the shares of the appellants as recorded in the khewats and khataunis of 1347 Fasli, this statement showed the total of the air area held by the appellants to be 152.33 acres, their khudkasht area to be 19.93 acres and the total of the local rate payable by them to be Rs. 75.5.11

facts.text: Statements showed total sir area 152.33 acres, khudkasht 19.93 acres, local rate Rs.75.5.11; none held >50 acres or >Rs.25/- local rate.

anchor.surface_text: this statement showed the total of the air area held by the appellants to be 152.33 acres, their khudkasht area to be 19.93 acres and the total of the local rate payable by them to be Rs. 75.5.11  b  a statement showing the air, khudkasht and local rate of each plain in 1317 Fasli. This shows that numbere of them held sir or sir and khudkasht in excess of 50 acres, or was assessed to local rate exceeding Rs. 25/-

facts.text: Supreme Court held substantial compliance with amended s.19 and rules 239A,239B; Board of Revenue erred in remanding.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Board of Revenue was in error in setting aside the decree of the Additional Commissioner and remanding the case for fresh trial on the ground that there had number been companypliance with the provisions of amended s. 19 of the Act and the rules framed thereunder.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeals, set aside Board order, remanded to Board to decide per law including adivasi rights contention.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeals, set aside the order of the Board of Revenue and remand the cases to it for decision in accordance with law. We further direct it to decide itself the companytention raised by the respondents about their having acquired adivasi rights under the U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Reforms Act. In case the Board takes the view that for deciding the said issue any finding of fact is necessary, it. may call for the said finding from the Trial Court and, on receiving it, proceed to deal with the appeals on the merits.

facts.text: Appeals pending before Additional Commissioner when Amendment Act came into force; to be decided per amended Act per s.31.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act defines sir. This section reads Sir means a land which immediately before the commencement of this Act was sir under the provisions of the Agra Tenancy Act, 1926, or the Oudh Rent Act, 1886 Provided that if at the commencement of this Act, the sir holder is assessed in the United Provinces to a local rate of more than twenty-five rupees, land which was sir, under the provisions of clause d or clause e of Section 4 of the Agra Tenancy Act, 1926, or of clause c or clause d of sub-Section 17 of Section 3 of the Oudh Rent Act, 1886 ,shall on this Act coming into force cease to be sir unless it was before the first day of July, 1938, received otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of Section 122 of the United Provinces Land Revenue Act, 1901

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Board of Revenue was in error in setting aside the decree of the Additional Commissioner and remanding the case for fresh trial on the ground that there had number been companypliance with the provisions of amended s. 19 of the Act and the rules framed thereunder.

holdings.text: The land in suit was sir on January 1, 1940, when the Act came into force, each sir-holder was not assessed to a local rate exceeding Rs. 25/- on relevant dates, and did not hold more than 50 acres of sir or sir and khudkasht land such that it did not cease to be sir under provisos to s.6.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from these provisions that the appellants bad to establish the following facts  i  The land in suit was sir on January 1, 1940, when the Act came into force.  ii  Each sir-holder was number assessed in the United Provinces to a local rate of more than Rs. 25/-.  iii  The sir holder or his predecessor in interest was number assessed to a local rate exceeding Rs. 25/- on June 30, 1938. The appellants proved these facts and the trial Court held that the land in suit did number cease to be sir. Further, if the finding had been that the first proviso to s. 6 applied, s. 16 would have

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants established facts through evidence; trial court findings confirmed by first appellate court that provisos to s.6 did not apply and area under s.16 limit satisfied.

holdings.text: Amended section 19 applies to appeals pending before Additional Commissioner when U.P. Tenancy Amendment Act, 1947 came into force.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this section, the appeals which. were pending before the additional Commissioner when the amendment Act came into force bad to be decided in accordance with the provisions of the Act as amended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 31 of Amendment Act mandates that pending proceedings be decided under amended provisions.

holdings.text: Amendment to section 19 effects no change in substantive law, only procedural requirement to furnish particulars before evidence for ascertaining s.6 proviso and s.16 area applicability.

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 therefore, did number bring about any real change in the substantive law affecting the question whether certain land is sir or number, according to the definition of sir in s. 6 of the Act. After the amendment, a sir-holder, in order to succeed in his suit, had to establish the same facts which he had to establish prior to the amendment... The only difference brought about by the amendment is in the procedural companyduct of the suit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sir-holder must prove same facts pre and post-amendment; amendment merely requires advance furnishing of particulars to assist court, with consequence for non-compliance.

holdings.text: Appellants substantially complied with requirements of amended s.19 and rules 239A, 239B by filing documents furnishing necessary particulars.

anchor.surface_text: The documents filed by the appellants in the Trial Court companysisted of  1  khewats of the various villages for the years 1345, 1346 and 1347 Fasli, i.e. for the periods between July 1, 1937 to June 30, 1940  2  khatauni jamabandis of the various villages for the years 1345 and 1347 Fasli, companyresponding to July 1, 1937 to June 30, 1938 and July 1, 1939 to June 30, 1940, respectively  3   a  a statement showing the shares of the appellants as recorded in the khewats and khataunis of 1347 Fasli, this statement showed the total of the air area held by the appellants to be 152.33 acres, their khudkasht area to be 19.93 acres and the total of the local rate payable by them to be Rs. 75.5.11

holdings.reasoning_summary: Filed khewats, khataunis, statements covered local rates, areas, shares for relevant Fasli years including 30.6.1938, 31.12.1939, 1.1.1940; purpose of assisting court on s.6 and s.16 served; Board overlooked documents.

holdings.text: Board of Revenue erred in holding no compliance with amended s.19 and rules and in remanding cases on that ground.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Board of Revenue was in error in setting aside the decree of the Additional Commissioner and remanding the case for fresh trial on the ground that there had number been companypliance with the provisions of amended s. 19 of the Act and the rules framed thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantial compliance established; Board's attention not drawn to relevant filed documents providing required particulars.

directions: set aside the order of the Board of Revenue
remand the cases to it for decision in accordance with law
decide itself the contention raised by the respondents about their having acquired adivasi rights under the U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Reforms Act
if necessary for deciding the said issue, call for finding of fact from the Trial Court and proceed to deal with the appeals on the merits

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Board of Revenue was in error in setting aside the decree of the Additional Commissioner and remanding the case for fresh trial on the ground that there had number been companypliance with the provisions of amended s. 19 of the Act and the rules framed thereunder.

We accordingly allow the appeals, set aside the order of the Board of Revenue and remand the cases to it for decision in accordance with law.
